subject: On PALM
msgSnippet: The PALM lexical set is pretty small, I should probably explain. It consists of words written al where the l is no longer pronounced, as in palm itself;
messageBody:
The PALM lexical set is pretty small, I should probably explain.
It consists of words written "al" where the "l" is no longer
pronounced, as in "palm" itself; foreign words where the original
vowel is preserved, like "drama" and "pasta" (though some speakers put
these in TRAP instead); and the special word "father", which should
have gone into FACE like other words with original long "a" if all
had gone as expected (and is so pronounced in broad Yorkshire), but
was reshaped, probably because it is a papa-mama word, and they never
follow the usual rules. (There's a nice writeup on such words at
http://www.sussex.ac.uk/linguistics/documents/where_do_mama2.pdf .)

Also, don't forget that even people who merge THOUGHT and PALM (and
therefore have CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM) don't merge NORTH/FORCE and START.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
Mr. Henry James writes fiction as if it were a painful duty. --Oscar Wilde

The PALM lexical set is pretty small, I should probably explain.
It consists of words written "al" where the "l" is no longer
pronounced, as in "palm" itself; foreign words where the original
vowel is preserved, like "drama" and "pasta" (though some speakers put
these in TRAP instead); and the special word "father", which should
have gone into FACE like other words with original long "a" if all
had gone as expected (and is so pronounced in broad Yorkshire), but
was reshaped, probably because it is a papa-mama word, and they never
follow the usual rules.  (There's a nice writeup on such words at
http://www.sussex.ac.uk/linguistics/documents/where_do_mama2.pdf .)

Also, don't forget that even people who merge THOUGHT and PALM (and
therefore have CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM) don't merge NORTH/FORCE and START.

--
